description:
One morning in the Tsukuda household, Hanpeita's sister, Tsukune, lets his pet bird escape out of spite. On the way home from school, she finds a strange egg from another planet and brings it home to give her brother, in order to make up for her earlier mistake. However, he isn't too pleased with it.

Not too long after, the egg swells up, cracks its shell, and out comes a pink, strange chicken-like alien creature named Ganmo! He speaks like a human being and comes to live with the Tsukudas. Not wanting to be a mere freeloader, Ganmo takes the initiative to run errands, clean the house, and do other menial chores, yet he blunders at everything he does. Everytime Ganmo tries to clear his reputation his efforts end up causing even more confusion.

A charming young, purple-haired girl named Ayumi Ichigaya moves next door to the Tsukudas. She has a strange pet myna bird named Déjà Vu. It's foppish with a poisonous tongue and always teases Ganmo for being so odd-looking.

And so begin the messed up daily lives of young Hanpeita and his new pet.

(Source: Wikipedia)

tags.name: Animals
tags.description: Prominently features animal characters in a leading role.

tags.name: Episodic
tags.description: Features story arcs that are loosely tied or lack an overarching plot.

tags.name: Slapstick
tags.description: Prominently features comedy based on deliberately clumsy actions or embarrassing events.

tags.name: School
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a primary or secondary educational institution.

tags.name: Nudity
tags.description: Features a character wearing no clothing or exposing intimate body parts.

name.native: リンダ・スカイラーク
ドロシー・スカイラーク

node.description: In 1979, Hosono made his debut with Crusher Joe while he was a student at Keio University. Around the same time, he joined the Studio Nue (スタジオぬえ) as an animator. He has had stories published in the manga anthology series Petit Apple Pie. He is the author of Gallery Fake and Tarō as well, for which two he won Shogakukan Manga Award for general manga in 1996.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/885163337809395712)

An irreplaceable member of the Japanese animation industry.

Inoue is an animator of the realist school whose skills are among the best in the world. He is known to often handle immense amounts of work in the titles he partakes in. Famous examples being the film [Maquia](https://anilist.co/anime/99457/), where he is responsible for a third of the film's animation, and [The Deer King](https://anilist.co/anime/102891/), in which he was in charge of over 400 layout cuts and 200 key animation cuts at the age of 60.

Inoue aspired to become an animator after having seen [Future Boy Conan](https://anilist.co/anime/302/) in 1978 as a high school student, a television series directed by [Hayao Miyazaki](https://anilist.co/staff/96870/). After graduation, Inoue took and failed the entrance exam for [Telecom Animation Film](https://anilist.co/studio/94/), an animation studio where Miyazaki was working at the time. He then joined [Studio Junio](https://anilist.co/studio/280/) and debuted as an in-betweener in 1982.

During his time at Junio he was heavily inspired by the likes of [Takashi Nakamura](https://anilist.co/staff/102031/) and [Satoru Utsunomiya](https://anilist.co/staff/101489/). A mere two years after his debut, Inoue started attracting attention with his work on [Gu-Gu Ganmo](https://anilist.co/anime/3020/) as a character designer and animation director, and was soon thereafter invited to join the productions of the high profile feature films; [The Wings of Honneamise](https://anilist.co/anime/1034/), [Akira](https://anilist.co/anime/47/) as well as [Kiki's Delivery Service](https://anilist.co/anime/512/), the fifth film of Hayao Miyazaki's. Ever since then he has been in high demand for feature films.

[Mamoru Oshii](https://anilist.co/staff/99097/) has praised him as "the perfect animator," who has "no need for a director." Adding that if you had five of him you could make a whole film. [Keiichi Hara](https://anilist.co/staff/104680/) has called him a "treasure of the anime industry," who "isn't only good, but also fast."

Inoue also devotes himself to teaching animation to the younger generation. In the early 2000s he presided over a cram school in his name for young animators at [Production I.G](https://anilist.co/studio/10/), a studio which Inoue still often works with to this day.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/885163337809395712)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/梶島正樹)

He entered [Studio Junio](https://anilist.co/studio/280/) after graduating from Osaka Design College. Kajishima admired [Kenichi Sonoda](https://anilist.co/staff/97942/)'s designs and came to Tokyo to join the [Gall Force](https://anilist.co/anime/2060/) production team. After Gall Force, he continued to do a bunch of contract work for [AIC](https://anilist.co/studio/48/) as a freelancer and became mainly known for creating the [Tenchi Muyou!](https://anilist.co/anime/696/) universe.

Besides his anime works, he's also written doujinshi and novels.

Miki Matsubara was a Japanese composer, lyricist, and singer from Kishiwada, Osaka, Japan. She participated in the opening and ending theme songs of the TV anime [Gu-Gu Ganmo](https://anilist.co/anime/3020/) under the name "Suzie Matsubara". Her 1979 debut song "Mayonaka no Door (Stay With Me)" became a hit, reaching number 28 on the Oricon chart, selling 104,000 copies according to Oricon survey, and selling 300,000 copies announced by Canyon Records. In addition, since around 2020, the song has become widely heard not only in Japan but also overseas thanks to the video sharing platform TikTok and the resurgence of city pop.
